multiple_choice_question.text: What do the diagrams in Figure 2 represent?
choices: Two different types of SCMMs.
Two different ways to visualize Deep Submodular Functions (DSFs).
Two different strategies for learning submodular functions.
Two different methods for representing feature redundancy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What concept is illustrated in Figure 3?
choices: The relationship between cycle matroids and DSFs.
The recursive definition of a laminar matroid rank function.
The application of DSFs in data summarization tasks.
The superiority of DSFs over SCMMs in representing all submodular functions.
A Venn diagram illustrating the relative sizes of different function families.
The hierarchical structure of a deep neural network.
The process of backpropagating surplus in a DSF.
The relationship between feature-based functions and matroid rank functions.
A Deep Submodular Function (DSF).
A Sum of Concave over non-negative Modular plus Modular function (SCMM).
A feature-based function.
The gain of an element in a submodular function.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between Formula (9) and Formula (1)?
choices: Formula (9) represents a DSF while Formula (1) represents an SCMM.
Formula (9) uses concave functions while Formula (1) uses convex functions.
Formula (9) applies to continuous variables while Formula (1) applies to discrete sets.
Formula (9) requires a bipartite graph while Formula (1) does not.
